title: 107_s3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Trauma Care Systems Planning and Development Act of 2002". Congress finds that there is a history of cooperation between the Federal Government and State governments in developing emergency medical services. Trauma is a leading cause of death in the US, with significant costs associated with traumatic injuries, especially from motor vehicle-related incidents. Many States lack comprehensive trauma care systems, hindering prompt emergency medical services. Improving these systems can reduce trauma-related deaths and enhance homeland defense preparedness. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS. In section 1201 of the Public Health Service Act, amendments include collecting, compiling, and disseminating information on trauma care and emergency medical services, with special consideration for rural areas. In section 1201 of the Public Health Service Act, amendments aim to enhance each State's trauma care capabilities, promote consistent trauma data collection, and categorization in a standardized manner. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include the establishment of a Clearinghouse on Trauma Care and Emergency Medical Services, redesignating sections, and improving trauma care in rural areas by including advanced trauma life support in model curricula. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act involve increasing communication and coordination with State trauma systems and requiring matching funds for subsequent fiscal years. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act require matching funds for subsequent fiscal years, with specific ratios for the fourth and fifth years of payments to the State. Subsection (b) is also modified to streamline the requirements. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include changes to section 1213, such as inserting "nationally recognized" in certain paragraphs and updating evaluation procedures. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act involve consultation with various medical professionals and trauma care specialists, updating data collection on trauma patients and deaths, and coordinating planning for trauma systems at the state level. The Public Health Service Act amendments involve coordinating trauma systems planning at the state level, updating data collection on trauma patients and deaths, and consulting with medical professionals and trauma care specialists. The Public Health Service Act is amended to update the model plan by the Secretary in 2002, require submission of trauma plans with changes and improvements made, and restrict the use of payments. The Public Health Service Act is amended to update funding authorization and make conforming amendments to various sections. The Secretary will contract the Institute of Medicine to conduct a study on trauma care and research, evaluating its state, clinical effectiveness, and obstacles. Special attention will be given to high-risk groups. The study will identify obstacles hindering trauma systems effectiveness, evaluate alternative strategies for trauma care organization, financing, and delivery, and assess the role of trauma systems in mass casualty preparedness. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years, with an authorization of $750,000 for fiscal years 2003 and 2004. Residency Training Programs in Emergency Medicine will also be addressed. Section 1251(c) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to change the years referenced. Section 1252 is amended to remove the word "demonstration" from the section heading. Section 1261 is amended to focus on basic and clinical research on trauma, including prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of trauma-related injuries. The Director will establish a plan for the Program based on recommendations from the NIH Trauma Research Task Force. Changes include updating terminology from "acute head injury" to "traumatic brain injury" and redesignating subsections.
